block.p: WAR IN THE GULF A10-A14

More than 80 Iraqi planes have flown to Iran in recent days, including more than 60 fighters and bombers. Allied planes have apparently succeeded in cutting off the flow of crude oil into the Persian Gulf. Page A1

Questions about Iran's intentions and avowed neutrality have risen with the flight of Iraqi planes to Iran, which said it would not allow them to leave. The nature of the flights strongly suggest Iran's advance approval. A1
Experts say human efforts are no match for the tide of oil A11
American companies want to help but fear the war zone A11
Oil companies announce higher fourth quarter profits D1

Iraqi forces will win the war, President Hussein said in his first interview with a western reporter since the war began. He suggested he would use chemical, biological and nuclear weapons if needed. A12

At least 324 Iraqi civilians have died and another 416 have been wounded by the American-led aerial bombardment, which has also destroyed religious, cultural and residential buildings, Iraq announced. A12 President Bush vowed to seek peace for "the rest of the Middle East" once the war in Iraq is over. In a speech intended to quiet Arab concerns, he said the United States does "not seek the destruction of Iraq." A13
In Washington, war becomes a surreal spectator sport A13
Polls show Western Europeans support the war A14

Many Israelis are fleeing Tel Aviv and the terror that has befallen it. Mayor Shlomo Lahat has called them "deserters," prompting a soul-searching about how Israelis should react to the Iraqi raids. A14
Saudis abandon town near the border to the troops A10
CBS says Saudi Arabia has impeded search for missing crew A10
Reporter's Notebook: It's hurry up and wait -- still A10

Military recruiters face a tough task convincing promising high school students, and their parents, that now is a good time to sign up, though there has been a surge in volunteers who are unqualified for service. A13 INTERNATIONAL A2-A9, A15

The summit meeting was postponed. U.S. and Soviet officials blamed the delay on the war in the Persian Gulf and the inability to conclude a long-range nuclear weapons treaty, not the situation in the Baltics. A1
Career diplomat to be the next Ambassador to Britain A6

The press in Haiti is struggling to redefine its role. Journalists are torn between cheering or criticizing the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the liberal priest elected President in Haiti's first free election. A3

Fighting has subsided in Somalia, as rebels seized the capital, forcingPresident Mohammed Siad Barre to flee. The rebel group, the Somali Congress, said it would form "a broad-based democratic government." A3
Cape Skirring Journal: Attacks shake Senegal's stability A4

Deng Xiaoping is politically active again after a year of quiet retirement. The 86-year-old leader appears to have directed key elements of national policy recently and helped the cause of the leaders he favors. A8
Japan is on guard after threats by terrorist group A9
India's poorest of the poor find a place in the economy A15 NATIONAL A16-A19

Is there a way to reverse poverty? Some have argued that the nation has run out of ideas for an anti-poverty policy, but many new proposals have arisen that need only money, consensus and committment to work. A1
Survey of college freshmen finds a shift to social concerns A18

The State of the Union Message that President Bush will deliver will focus primarily on the war, but it will also address domestic issues and offer new proposals to revamp the nation's banking laws, officials said. A16

The American Civil Liberties Union, facing a change in leadership andmission, put itself at the center of another issue far from the center, announcing it would fight civil liberties abuses caused by the war. A16
Ruling on tapes clears the way for Manuel Noriega's trial A16
News analysis: The long papal letter that called on Catholics to spread the faith through missionary work is renewing debate in the United States over the role of missionaries. A19
More blacks favor "black" than "African-American" A19 REGIONAL B1-3

The City Council wielded its power under the new City Charter, forcing Fire Commissioner Carlos Rivera to testify under oath and threatening to subpoena two more agencies in its investigation of bridge safety. A1

New York State's gasoline tax would rise by 10 cents a gallon -- to more than double the current 8-cent tax -- as part of Governor Cuomo's plan to close the $6 billion deficit in the state's budget, officials said. B1

Governor Weicker is prepared to cut the budget for the next fiscal year by 10 percent, but he said that Connecticut's shortfall in tax revenues is so large that residents face $1 billion or more in new or higher taxes. B1

Property taxes on affordable housing in New Jersey must be reduced to take into consideration restrictions of the resale value of the houses, not the full market value, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled. B1
Governor Florio approves an increase in turnpike tolls B2

Deposits at Freedom National Bank were sharply cut by the Treasury Department, hastening the collapse of the small Harlem bank, even as pub- lic deposits were used to shore up the Bank of New England. A1

Polish-Americans have been stunned by the disappearance of millions of dollars in savings from Stockbridge Funding, a mortgage banking corporation owned by a Polish-American businessman from Brooklyn. B1

A shipment of cocaine was seized from an oil tanker in New York Harbor. Divers found the cocaine in an airpocket in the rudder, guarded by two Colombians who had survived five days in the compartment. A1
Talks between Daily News and its unions begin again B3
Fire destroys kitchen of Ratner's Dairy Restaurant B3
Four named to editing posts at The New York Times C15
Neediest Cases B2 BUSINESS DIGEST D1 Science Times
Guarding the bomb: A perfect record, but can it last? C1
The search for signs of global warming C1
Dissecting leaders' psyches from afar C1
Virus could have a role in clogging of arteries C3 Arts/Entertainment
Disparities in videotape pricing C11
The second 'Miss Saigon" C11
Music: Mozart bicentennial opens C12
Word and Image:Critic's NotebookC11 Obituaries B4-5
Harold (Red) Grange, football star B5 Fashion Page B6 Sports
Basketball: Tucker rejoins Knick starters B11
Football: 'Maybes' don't trouble Anderson B7
Sleepless night is well worth it B7
The Bills' longest day B7
Parcells's philosophy prevails B8
Hockey: Rangers enjoy timeout B9 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed
